```{r set-up}
library(tidyverse)
library(palmerpenguins)
library(broom)
library(ggridges)
library(infer)

evals_small <- moderndive::evals %>% 
  group_by(prof_ID) %>% 
  mutate(min_eval = min(score), 
         age_cat = case_when(age < 37 ~ "young faculty",
                             age >= 37 & age < 45 ~ "middle age", 
                             age >= 45 & age < 60 ~ "older faculty", 
                             age >= 60 ~ "nearly retired"),
         age_cat = factor(age_cat, 
                          levels = c("young faculty", "middle age",
                                     "older faculty", "nearly retired")
                          )
         ) %>% 
  distinct(prof_ID, .keep_all = TRUE) 
```

Data Visualization Principles 
:::

. . .

::: columns
::: {.column width="45%"}
[Edward Tufte](https://thedoublethink.com/tuftes-principles-for-visualizing-quantitative-information/)
![](images/tufte.gif)

*Minimalism*

:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {style="font-size: 0.75em; color: #FFFFFF;"}
> One of Tufte's ideas is data-to-ink ratio, generally stating that when creating a visualization, you should try to maximize the amount of "ink" (physical or digital) used to represent the data, and minimize the amount used to represent everything else not important to understanding.

:::
:::
:::

##

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"}
`theme_classic()` in `ggplot()`
:::

```{r minimal}
#| echo: false
#| fig-align: center

ggplot(data = penguins, 
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, 
                     y = bill_depth_mm, 
                     color = species)) + 
  geom_point() +
  labs(y = "Bill Depth (mm)", 
       x = "Bill Length (mm)", 
       color = "Penguin Species") +
  theme_classic()
```

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"}
Gestalt Principles
:::

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
[Gestalt psychology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gestalt_psychology) is a theory of perception that believes humans are inclined to understand objects as an entire structure rather than the sum of its parts.
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="55%"}
[Gestalt Principles for Data Visualization](https://medium.com/nightingale/how-to-apply-gestalt-psychology-principles-in-data-visualization-6242f4f1a3de)

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em; color: #FFFFFF;"}
> The Figure and Ground Principle describes the capacity to perceive the relationship between form and surrounding space to create meaning. A sense of wholeness or unity depends on how you perceive the relationship between an object and the area in which it is contained. The ‘figure’ is the focus element, while the ‘ground’ is the figure’s background.

:::
:::
:::

##  {background-color="#B6CADA"}

::: {style="font-size: 4em; color: #000000;"}
Goal of an ANOVA
:::

Analysis of variance (ANOVA) compares the means of three of more groups
to detect if the means of the groups are different.

## 

::: {style="font-size: 4em; color: #B6CADA;"}
**How???**
:::

- Compare how different a group of means are
- Scale the differences relative to the variability of the groups
- Summarize the differences with one number

##

::: {style="font-size: 3.5em; color: #FFFFFF;"}
Visualizing Group Differences
:::

</br>

We want visualizations that allow for us to easily compare:  

- the center (mean) of the groups 
- the spread (variability) of the groups 

##

```{r age-cat-density}
#| echo: false
#| out-width: 70%

ggplot(data = evals_small, 
       mapping = aes(y = age_cat, x = min_eval)) + 
  geom_density_ridges() + 
  labs(y = "Professor's Age", 
       x = "Minimum Evaluation Score") +
  theme(axis.title = element_text(size = 18), 
        axis.text.y = element_text(size = 16), 
        axis.text.x = element_text(size = 14))
```

::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #B6CADA;"}
What can you say about the differences between the groups?

What can you say about the variability within the groups?
:::

##

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"}
**F-distribution**
:::

An $F$-distribution is a variant of the $t$-distribution, and is also defined by degrees of freedom. 

. . .

</br>

This distribution is defined by __two__ different degrees of freedom:  

1. from the numerator (MSG) : $k - 1$
2. from the denominator (MSE) : $n - k$ 

##

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"}
Two degrees of freedom!
:::

</br>

:::

##

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"}
**Conditions of an ANOVA**
:::

- Independence 
  * Within groups 
  * Between groups
  
- Normality of the responses
  * The distribution of each group is approximately normal

- Equal variability of the groups 
  * The spread of the distributions are similar across groups

Simulation-based Methods
:::

##

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"}
Step 1: Calculating the Observed F-statistic
:::

```{r}
#| echo: true
obs_F <- evals_small %>% 
  specify(response = min_eval, 
          explanatory = age_cat) %>% 
  calculate(stat = "F")
```

```{r}
obs_F
```

##

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"}
Step 2: Simulating what could have happened under $H_0$
:::

. . .

</br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #B6CADA;"}
How could we use cards to simulate what minimum evaluation score a professor would have gotten, if their score was independent from their age?
:::


##

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"}
Another Permutation Distribution
:::

```{r null-dist}
#| echo: true
null_dist <- evals_small %>% 
  specify(response = min_eval, 
          explanatory = age_cat) %>% 
  hypothesize(null = "independence") %>% 
  generate(reps = 2000, type = "permute") %>% 
  calculate(stat = "F")
```

##

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"}
Another Permutation Distribution
:::

```{r}
#| out-width: 70%
#| out-height: 50%
visualise(null_dist)
```

. . .

</br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #B6CADA;"}
Why doesn't the distribution have negative numbers?
:::

##

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"}
Visualizing the p-value
:::

```{r, eval = FALSE}
#| echo: true
visualise(null_dist) + 
  shade_p_value(obs_stat = obs_F, direction = "greater")
```

</br>

```{r}
#| out-height: 50%
#| out-width: 70%

p_val <- get_p_value(null_dist, obs_stat = obs_F, direction = "greater") %>% 
  pull()
  
null_dist %>% 
  visualise() + 
  shade_p_value(obs_stat = obs_F, direction = "greater") + 
  annotate(x = pull(obs_F) + 0.5, y = 500, geom = "text", label = p_val, size = 6)
```
